review_title: Great staff, culture seems to be on the upswing
pros:
- Colleagues absolutely dedicated to the mission and by and large great people to work with
- Positive changes in my department related to increasing our capacity and getting tools to do our work better
- Regular all-staff meetings where real commentary is encouraged
- Frequent communication from leadership, including interim CEO, when something important is going on, like our yearly financial audit or yearly state evaluation
- Great mission, long standing in the community, knowing we are helping people
cons:
- Interim CEO is great, but a permanent hire would be a stabilizing force. Word is that it is in progress, but definitely taking a while.
- Daily Camera articles were embarrassing and have prompted uncomfortable questions in the community about whether we are going under (we aren't), whether we all go around with dark clouds over our heads (we don't), whether the culture is fearful or oppressive (it isn't).
- PTO accrual is not super generous
- Seems like many staff are still feeling cautious about the changes implemented since August. I came on right around that transition time and so perhaps don't have the history that some folks have, but many of my colleagues have been here 3,5,10 years and enjoy their work. I have every intention of staying here too--I like it here. And, while I think it has its ups and downs (like any company), I don't see any reason I wouldn't stick around.

job_title: RN Clinical Manager in Lafayette, CO
pros: There are many wonderful, caring staff providing hospice care to patients and their families despite the senior management.
cons: I wish I had read the reviews of this place before I moved here from another state for a position at this agency.  Read the two articles published summer 2016 in Boulders Daily Camera newspaper.  It's all true.  This agency is a nightmare to work for. They deposed the CEO but the problems run far deeper than that. Senior management run it like a sorority. They haze anyone who doesn't "fit in" with their model of secrecy and misinformation, then fire people with no warning, without cause.  Multiple people were literally escorted out the door in the 7 months I worked there. It's a culture of fear and intimidation. You never know who's office will be empty tomorrow.  This place is always hiring, not because of growth, but just to replace the people they dispose of.

job_title: RN Hospice Nurse in Lafayette, CO
pros: I have been working at TRU for the past 5 years and am very impressed by the passion the agency has to provide stellar patient care.  As a hospice nurse of over 15 years, (working for now three agencies) I can honestly say that TRU exceeds the quality of care of other hospice agencies.  One of the most important differences with TRU as compared to other hospice agencies is their after-hours support team.  Whereas most other hopices have only 1-2 nurses simply on-call, TRU has a nurse answering the phones with several nurses working in the field, as well  as providing chaplain and/or social workers’ on call if a family or patient requires emotional support.  This allows me and all the day nurses and staff, to be able to leave work at work.  I never have to feel concern or stress that my patients will not have the support needed at night.  This is huge!  Also, most hospice agencies do not hired full time physicians, making it more difficult to get MD support right away.  TRU has 3 full time MD’s as well as a NP!  This allows access to an MD to  immediately obtain assistance and education to me as well as immediate assistance for medication changes and prescription fills.  I am only pointing out a few of the advantages of working for TRU.  There are several other benefits and programs TRU offers which no other hospice organization does!
cons: Although TRU went through a time where a nurses census was higher than normal, the management changes have allowed for a shift in priority making it TRU’s priority to get patient loads down.  I love my job and love being able to work hard to care for those at the end of life, and most of all being able to rest and care for myself so that I may keep doing this job for many more years to come.
